Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Understanding Photochemical 2H-1T Phase Transition in Monolayer MoS2
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical Description: Ultra-thin transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) materials are promising candidates for flexible, low-power and transparent electronics and optoelectronics. Manipulating the atomic arrangements, referred to as crystal phases, can transform TMDs from semiconducting to metallic materials, which is a promising way to improve the overall device performance and/or to attain new functionalities. The current phase-engineering methods either rely on expensive and hostile chemicals or are incompatible with large-scale manufacturing. This project aims to develop a novel photochemical approach, which is controllable, scalable, low-cost, environmentally benign and compatible with electronic device fabrication, to induce phase-change in molybdenum disulfide. The research advances the state of knowledge of the phase-change mechanisms in TMD materials and explores the potential of TMD materials for applications in wearable electronics, foldable displays and lightings, and advanced integrated medical devices. The research effort is integrated with education and outreach activities, including training students in TMD materials, organizing a summer science camp and research internship programs for high school students that are traditionally underrepresented in the STEM field.

Technical Description: This project proposes a novel photochemical concept for phase transition in monolayer molybdenum disulfide to address the pressing need for performance improvement in 2D-TMD based electronic/optoelectronic devices. The goal of this EAGER project is to understand photochemically induced 2H to 1T phase transformation in monolayer molybdenum disulfide and to establish processing-structure and structure-property correlations. In pursuit of this goal, the project objectives are to (1) validate the phase change mechanism through systematic characterizations of photo-chemically formed hetero-phase molybdenum disulfide and evaluate the controllability of the transition by varying processing parameters; (2) investigate the stabilization mechanism of the metastable metallic phase for improved device reliability; and (3) evaluate intriguing optical and electrical properties of phase-engineered molybdenum disulfide. Combined approaches of advanced structural characterization, optical analysis, device fabrication and electrical measurements are used in this research to gain fundamental understandings of the phase-change mechanism and the phase-engineered 2D-TMD materials.

Institution.Name: University of California-Riverside
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA AT RIVERSIDE

POR.DRECONTENT:
This one-year EAGER grant supported the development of a novel photochemical approach to phase-engineer single layer MoS2 to improve its electron transport properties and bring its full potential for applications in ultrathin, flexible, low-power and transparent electronics and optoelectronics. By replacing   expensive and hostile organometallic compounds used in prevailing phase-engineering methods with low-cost and environmentally benign chemicals, the mild photochemical approach converts the single layer MoS2 from the semiconducting phase to a more conductive metallic phase in a controllable, scalable, cost-efficient fashion.

A first outcome of this program was that the major goal in validating the photochemical phase change mechanism was achieved. Through a combination of structural and optical characterizations, it was demonstrating that in the presence of a mild reductant, visible light can offer the activation energy needed to induce phase change in single layer MoS2 without observable damage or chemical residues on the surface that might impair the electrical transport properties of the material. The influences of processing parameters were also investigated. The impact of these efforts is that the mechanistic feasibility is now established, justifying more substantial investigation in application of the method to device fabrication and to other single layer transition metal dichalcogenides (TMD) materials.

The award also resulted in major progress on the development of a novel clean transfer technique of high-quality MoS2 and other two dimensional (2D) semiconductors, broadly applicable to both the fundamental research of 2D material and their heterostructure and the fabrication of high-performance 2D electronic and optoelectronic devices. Currently, clean transfer techniques rely on sacrificial layers or bulky crystal flakes to pick-up the 2D material. Under this NSF award, a capillary-force-assisted clean-stamp technique was developed, which uses a thin layer of distilled water as an “instant glue” to increase the adhesion energy between the 2D material and a silicone rubber stamp to pick it up. After water evaporates, the adhesion decreases, and the 2D layers can be released. This method ensures the low contamination level on the 2D materials and largely preserves their native chemical and electrical properties. Graphene-based transistors fabricated with this method demonstrated record high room temperature carrier mobility (up to 48,820 cm2 V-1 s-1), approaching the theoretical limit. 2D heterostructure optoelectronic devices with high operation speed was also successfully demonstrated.

The EAGER award was successful in delivering the intended feasibility outputs and a highly efficient clean transfer technique that will serve as the basis of more in-depth study of properties of the phase-engineered MoS2. Henceforth, most of our effort will be focused on combining the clean transfer technique and photochemical phase change mechanism to develop reliable fabrication methods for the systematic study of electronic and optoelectronic properties of the phase-engineered MoS2. The clean transfer method will greatly improve device success rate and reliability by minimizing sample variation and contamination.  

 


Last Modified: 11/28/2017
Modified by: Ruoxue Yan
